content: Legend of the Holy Cross before Christ (fragments)

notes.head: Addition
notes.body: (fol. 1r) […]don. Ða færinga heom eallum on ha[...]| aspráng þær fyr on ðreo halfe þæs treopes. 7 forbærnde s[...] | manna þe hit ceorfan ƿoldon. 7 ðone preost forð mid. þe h[…] | heretoga ƿæs. Ða oþre for þære miclan fyrhto þe hi þær g[...]| ut æturnon. þa hi ðanon ut comon þa gesaƿon hi 7 eal seo[…] | ƿaru on hierusalem […]

notes.head: Addition
notes.body: (fol. 1r) þa eodon hi in to ðam cyninge 7 him cyddon þæt hi o[..]allum| […]swulc treow findan [...] mihton swylc þær to sceolde | [...] þ[...] most[...] Salomon þæt he natoshwan þafian | [...] þing[...] iþe micle | [...]acun [...]ðer gehit on [...]gre oþre | [...]an mag [...]on. […] on seofon niht[…]n socne[…]

notes.head: Addition
notes.body: (fol. 1v) […]rto. þe hit ær ametan hæf[don] [...]| [...]am fæðmon lengre ðonne þæt gemett ƿære. Ða ƿæron hi sƿyþe | […]am cyninge cyþdon. 7 se cyning ofostlice þider geƿende. | […]s soðef ƿære. Ða he ða þæt geseah. Þa ƿearþ he mid | [...]sse onstyred. 7 [...] þæt hi deaþes scyldige wæron | […] gebroht hæfdon […] Het hit ða up[…]

objectDesc.extent:
74 mm x 145 mm (dimensions of Fragment 1 - size of leaf).
48 mm x 140 mm (dimensions of Fragment 1 - size of written space).

binding: In 1952 the two fragments were mounted in a paper frame by V. S. Stoakley. In 1991-2 Nicholas Hadgraft made a butterly pressure mount made of acid- free board with fitted recesses for each fragment (Doane 2002, p. 1).

history.origin: The glosses by the Tremulous Hand suggest that the fragments come from Worcester. Ker (1940) observed a resemblance between the scripts of 2:2 and Ker's Scribe 9 of Cambridge, CCC 198, causing Colgrave and Hyde (1962) to suggest that the fragments were once bound with Cambridge, CCC 198 or 'a similar manuscript which has now disappeared' (p. 77).
history.provenance: May have remained in Worcester until Archbishop Parker's time. Ker 1957 argues that it is not unlikely that Parker would have discarded this leaf because it was part of a text that began or ended imperfectly.
history.acquisition: 2:1 was used as strips in the binding of SP. 260, Fides Iesu et Iesuitarum &c. (Christlingæ 1573). It was found in the early 1950s. 2:2 was used as strips in the binding of SP. 4, Tertia pars chronici Carionis (Bas. 1563). It was found in 1936 and reported by Ker in 1940. Both books are from the library of Archbishop Parker, with 16th-century Parkerian bindings, and were given to Corpus Christi College in 1575 (Doane 2002, p. 1).

admin: Manuscript description by Hollie Morgan and Owen Roberson with the assistance of Sanne van der Schee, with reference to published scholarship (2010; 2012).
